Shi Chushi, secular surname Zhou, from Shu.
He served Chan Master Baoxiu, was frugal in clothing and food, and did not compete with others.
He was well-versed in the profound principles and lived on the northern mountain, practicing the Dhuta practices.
Empress Wu heard of him and ordered him to enter the palace, bestowing him with a monastic robe. He declined and begged to return to the mountain.
He spent 40 years, never setting foot in a village.
Sitting on a single mat, he was silent and did not sleep.
A tiger always crouched at the foot of his seat, like a domesticated animal.
The people of Zizhou respected him, and those who studied his way flocked to him.
Because of this, he often displayed strange and unusual phenomena, such as:
The master of no-characteristics came from the Silla kingdom to visit Chan master Shen. Beforehand, Shen warned the assembly:
An outsider guest will arrive tomorrow.
You should sweep and wait for him.
The next day, indeed, a guest from the East Sea arrived.

In the beginning of the Kaiyuan era, the newly appointed prefect Wang Ye, originally a Daoist priest, had once made a minor contribution during the Jingyun period. He was appointed to this prefecture and ended up harboring ill intentions towards the Buddhist disciples.
Upon taking office, he ordered all monks within the prefecture to be summoned.
Only Shiji had not come down from the mountain for a long time. Some advised Shiji to go and pay respects, to avoid being punished.
Shiji said to his disciples:
Although you have left home, you still do not understand karma. While I am not yet dead, what can Wang Ye do to me?
On the third day of Wang Gong's and Shangguan's arrival, the Buddhist disciples all gathered.
Some said:
Only Shiji disregards the feudal lord and does not come to pay respects.

Ye was slightly angry. He forced the monks to ascend to the hall and sit. After he was about to start his angry words, he asked about Shiji's refusal. His angry expression became more intense, and the monks all trembled in fear.
Ye suddenly fell to the ground. His attendants supported him back home. When he reached the back of the hall, there was a sound like being slapped on the cheek by a tree. At noon, he died.
From then on, people considered it a delusion to add to the monks, and it ended up like this.
Shiji passed away in the first month of the twenty-second year of Kaiyuan, at the age of eighty-seven.
People in Zizhong still revere him.

He focused his mind on the great way and made up his mind to travel around. He arrived at Yunhua Temple in the capital and studied the teachings of the Huayan Sutra under Dharma Master Chengguan.

Carefully observing the place where Shan'ong stood, there was white cloud slowly rising, about a foot off the ground, transforming into five-colored clouds and mist, above which a great sage riding a lion was surrounded by bodhisattvas.
In a short while, a section of white cloud in the east gradually covered the bodhisattva's face, and the group of images disappeared with the cloud.
Zha suddenly saw the six people, including the abbot of Puzhao Temple in Fenzhou, Xiu Zheng, coming back to the cave and bowing.
Suddenly they heard the mountain rocks shaking and roaring, with a sound like thunder, and the monks ran away.
After a long while, it was quiet and nothing was seen.
Zha then recounted his encounter, and the six people regretted not seeing the holy countenance, knowing that the distance of a few feet was due to the obstruction of karmic hindrances.
Zha then disappeared in the mountain and passed away.
In the Yuanhe period, Wen Yi of the gate pursued and recounted it.
Biography of Puhua of Zhen Ding Prefecture in Tang Dynasty, Biography of Puhua of Zhen Ding Prefecture in Tang Dynasty, Shi Puhua, whose place of origin is unknown.
His temperament was unusual, and he was often straightforward, acting simply and freely, and speaking without restraint.
He personally served Chan Master Panshan Ji, who secretly instructed him, and he deeply penetrated the hall and treasury. He was warned to take care of himself, but he acted wildly and perversely.
Once, when he met with Linji Xuan, he responded to him with a donkey bray, and those standing by could not help but laugh.
Sometimes he would sing and dance, and sometimes he would wail.
When people approached him, he would change a thousand times and ten thousand times, with little consistency.
One day, he carried a coffin on his back and went around the streets, announcing:
Puhua will die tomorrow.
At that time, people looked at him and knew he was beyond reproach.
The people of Zhao followed him out of the east gate of the city, and he said:
The burial today does not match the 'blue crow'.
After two days, he went out the southern gate, and people followed him again, saying:
Tomorrow will be auspicious.
In this way, he went out the western gate and the northern gate, and returned, the people were tired and their minds were weary.
One day, he sat in the suburbs as if entering meditation.
As for the author of the Chan school's writings, he considers his words to be from the enlightened ones, and ranks Puhua in the category of scattered sages, saying that his words are not orthodox.

The Biography of Dachao of Qixian Temple in Hanzhou, Tang Dynasty, by Fajing of Qixian Temple in Hanzhou, Tang Dynasty. Dachao, whose place of origin is unknown, lived in silence and his integrity was even more severe.
His precepts were without flaw, and his words were not wasted.
At Qixian Temple in Hanzhou, he practiced the four kinds of holy seeds, and as his austerity increased, his joy also increased.
The people of Mianzhu, who had no previous faith, all became his followers.
When he passed away, he was laid outside the temple. The laypeople prepared beds and couches, carried him back to the temple together, and diligently arranged funeral rites.
Just as they were about to lift the corpse, a pair of deer led the way in front, as if guiding them.
As soon as they stepped over the temple threshold, the temple plaque suddenly fell to the ground. The people near and far were amazed.
Moreover, the spiritual anomalies of this mountain do not tolerate vulgarity.
There was a monk named Shen Cang who was not careful in his vows and often violated them.
The divine person threw him to the foot of the mountain, about seven li away, only injuring his toe.
From then on, no one dared to violate the precepts.
In the beginning of the Dali era, the northern mountain turned into a golden color, with a pavilion above, where bodhisattvas practiced the Way.
In a moment, there were myriad forms and a thousand appearances.
Xuan resided in this temple, and together with the land, he was spiritual. He left a shadow for worship, as if serving a spiritual shrine.

Next, Fajing of Fuzhou City, whose place of origin is unknown, practiced the dhuta method, persevering in hardship and diligence, inspiring the people of Fuzhou with his straightforward words and demeanor.
He heard that in the waters of Lianmen Bay in Haitan there was a giant bell, which was said to have been cast by someone who went to Guangzhou to raise funds for a trust drum.
The huge ship arrived here, but suddenly encountered wind and waves that sank it.

On the day of each month's full moon, when the tide came in, the water receded, and the giant clam emerged, large enough to accommodate a person passing through its center, with a circumference of over ten zhang.

During the Dali era, Fajing wanted to extract this bell. He first held a grand assembly and recitation at Kaigen Temple, and sent a young monk to the Dragon Palace to beg for the bell to be used in the human world, to be struck to signal the morning and evening.
The young monk saw the sea god and said:
I cherish it to guard the sea.
He gave him three small pearls as a token of faith. At that moment, the young monk felt as if he had awakened from a dream, and the pearls were in his hand.

Biography of Nata of the Western Regions during the Tang Dynasty, Biography of Nata of the Western Regions during the Tang Dynasty Shi Nata, which means joy in Chinese, is not known what country he was from.
As for his character, he was strange and unconventional, with no fixed sense of respect or contempt.
During the Jian period, he somehow arrived in Min and Shu, at that time Zhang Yanshou was the governor of Chengdu.
Nata said, I have attained the samÄdhi of illusion - I can enter water without getting wet, throw myself into fire without being burned, transform gold and stone, and manifest endlessly.

When he first entered Shu, he traveled with three young nuns, sometimes getting very drunk and singing wildly, sometimes gathering crowds to preach the Dharma. The garrison general deeply disliked him and repeatedly ordered him to be captured.
Nata was captured and taken to him, and said:
I have taken refuge in the monks' order, but I have my own medical skills.
He then pointed to the three nuns and said:
They are all skilled in singing and dancing.
The garrison commander valued him highly, so he kept him and provided wine and meat, and they drank and sang together at night.

He borrowed a robe, trousers, and a hair ribbon, and the three nuns each applied powder and rouge. They all sat in a row, their eyes gazing and smiles charming, their unrestrained manner surpassing the world.
When they had drunk about half, Xi said to the nuns:
Can you dance for the garrison commander?
So they slowly advanced to dance, trailing silk and swirling like snow, rising swiftly and touching their knees, their skill again surpassing that of others.
After a long while, the tune ended but the dance did not stop. Xi then scolded:
Women's wayward ways!
Xi suddenly got up, took the garrison commander's sword, and the crowd thought he was drunk. Those sitting all ran away in fright.
He then cut off the heads of the three nuns, all of which fell to the ground, with blood reaching several dozen feet.
The garrison commander was greatly startled and called to his men to bind Xi.
Xi laughed and said:
Don't be rash.
Xu raised the three nuns, which were bamboo staffs, and the blood was the wine he had drunk before.
Xi then sat back to drink and feast, and ordered someone else to cut off his head, nailing his two ears to the pillar, both without any blood stains.
The body then sat on the mat, and when the wine was poured, it flowed into the severed part, and the face also turned red.
And the mouth could sing and dance, and the hands clapped in time to the beat.
When the feast was over, the body rose by itself, went to the pillar to take the head and put it on, and there were no scars.
From time to time, he spoke of people's good and bad fortune, often in riddles, which were only understood after the fact.
Someone in Chengdu made offerings to him, and after several days, Xi suddenly did not want to stay, so he locked the door to keep him.
Xi then entered the wall crack, and when pulled, he gradually sank in, leaving only the corner of his kasaya, and soon disappeared.
The next day, he saw a painted monk on the wall, whose appearance was like the color of the sun, gradually sinking every other day.
After seven days, there were ink traces in the sky.
By the eighth day, the ink traces had disappeared.
Some people saw him early, already in the Pengzhou area.
Later, no one knew where he went.
Xi said:
Is Nandi's appearance and behavior correct or incorrect?
Yet he said he attained the illusory samÄdhi, and the same samÄdhi as King AÅ›oka is the great concentration of all buddhas.
Only one who is illusory sees the illusory, and the realm cannot be divided by verbal discussion.
The four spiritual powers have the illusory power, which can transform external things.
Therefore, Nandi awakened the people of Yong and Shu, who mostly admired the way of ghosts and immortals.
Without this samÄdhi, it would not be enough to transform the worldly people who are difficult to transform.

The Biography of Xuanzong of Mount Zima in Shouzhou during the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Xuanzong of Mount Zima in Shouzhou during the Tang Dynasty, Shi Xuanzong, whose surname was Wu, was from Yongjia.
After a short time, he left the dust [of the world] and had a broad and generous bearing. He relied on Changjing as his teacher at Baoshou Temple on Mount Yongding in his own prefecture.
After Zhi obtained the precepts, he traveled to various places to study. He arrived at the gate of Chan Master Cilang in Jiangling, like true gold being refined.
He resolved his doubts and uncertainties, and again shook his staff to go elsewhere. He saw Mount Zishan and was delighted in his heart. He stayed to practice Chan meditation.
This mountain had previously been full of tigers that were violent. They would sometimes bite travelers or injure woodcutters - those who avoided harsh government policies cried out in grief.
From Zong's divination of his dwelling, the tigers' growls and tracks disappeared. From then on, those entering the mountain were not afraid.
One day, the Chan practitioners gathered and saw an old man rush to the front of the seat, bowing and kneeling diligently.
Zong asked:
Who are you?
He replied:
I was originally a tiger. I ate living beings on this mountain.
Because of the great master's transformation, my mind turned to the dark [truth], I escaped from my karmic body, and was already reborn in the heavens, so I came to repay my gratitude.
In the blink of an eye, I could not see anything.
In the second year of Dali, he took leave of his disciples and suddenly passed away.
He was eighty-six years old. He entered the stupa in the second month. A stele was erected and preserved.
Tang Dynasty, Biography of Guangfu of Yangqi Mountain in Yuanzhou, Tang Dynasty, Biography of Guangfu of Yangqi Mountain in Yuanzhou, Shi Guangfu, a layman surnamed Zheng, was from Nanyue.
When he was young, he followed the virtuous monk Si Hao to receive the Dharma teachings.
After completing the precepts, he traveled to Songshan and the two capitals. He met Chan Master Shenhui and greatly illuminated the profound meaning.
He arrived at Yangqi Mountain in Yichun and hung his robe there - in this place, the peaks accumulated mist, the caves were secluded, and the sprouts of mushrooms grew among the grasses and plants.
Fu spent the whole day with his eyes closed, eating wood to pass the time.
At that time, there were those wearing lofty crowns and feathered robes, riding cranes and phoenixes, who would suddenly come and go, and later ascend to the hermitage and approach his knees.
Wherever the immortal guests arrived, there would be light clouds and mist, following their steps.
The celestial attendants and strongmen were ordered to go far away, and they conversed and discussed for a long time.
Later, when his Way had been accomplished, he entered nirvana on the fourth day of the third month in the first year of the Zhenyuan era, at the age of ninety-one.
The author says:
The ways of immortals and deities are different, how can their discussions be the same?
The author replies:

In the past, there were some true people who could discuss the principle of emptiness. The immortals in the mountains who established Buddhism sincerely revered the Buddha's Way, but they did not shave their heads or dye their robes, and were called 'lay bodhisattvas'.
Moreover, the immortals in the Snow Mountains were skilled in the Five Sciences, and those who sought to cross over were the same.
However, their similar ways must be distinguished.
If the five subtle elements and five great elements in the twenty-five principles of the Western Regions have the same names as the Buddhist teachings,

the theories of the gods are very different, and it is difficult to distinguish them.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:ğŸ”½Biography of Shi Yuanzhen of Wuyashan in Dengzhou during the Tang Dynasty
Shi Yuanzhen, whose surname was Chen, was a person from Zhongshan.
He was intelligent and fond of learning from a young age. He entered the school and studied the Five Classics.
Suddenly, he encountered a wandering monk who stayed overnight. His father, who was a local official, had a strong interest in the Way and kept the monk to provide offerings.
Yuanzhen paid respects to the monk and listened to his talks on the Way, which made him feel deeply enlightened.
He abandoned the Confucian classics and studied Buddhist scriptures. He suddenly left his loved ones and went to Baizimai Mountain to pay respects to Zhi You as his teacher and receive teachings.
Later, he met Chan Master Heshang and attained the Dharma. He then secluded himself at Wuyashan in Nanyang.
Before this, there were many giant snakes in the mountain, and there was a poisonous dragon in a cave. The villagers suffered from them.
When Zhen resided here, the two creatures hid their tracks.
Once there was a person whose appearance and clothing were unusual. He bowed and said:

I have been here for two hundred years. Now I am moved by the teaching of no-mind and the cultivation of cutting off thoughts. We, the obscurely responsive ones, transcend and ascend. Could it not be the power of the teacher?
In the sixth year of the Zhenyuan era, he passed away at the age of eighty-six. His disciples respectfully enshrined his whole body in a stupa.
The Biography of Dizang of Huacheng Temple on Mount Jiuhua in Chizhou Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty. Shi Dizang, whose surname was Jin, was a descendant of the king of Silla.
He had a kind heart but an ugly appearance, and was naturally intelligent.
He had a body seven feet tall, with a unique bone protruding from the top of his head, and was exceptionally tall. He had the strength to rival ten men.
He once admonished himself, saying:
In the six classics of the world and the three teachings of Daoism, only the supreme truth can be in harmony with the mind.
At that time, he shaved his head, crossed the sea, left the boat and traveled on foot, shaking his staff and observing the world.
He happened to arrive in Chiyang and saw Mount Jiuzhi, and his heart was very happy. He then went straight to the peak and found a place in the valley, facing the sun and wide and flat.
The soil was black and fertile, and the spring water was smooth and sweet. Living in the cliffs and drawing water from the streams, he passed his days as he pleased.
Zang was once bitten by a poisonous insect, but he sat upright without any thought.
Suddenly, a beautiful woman appeared, bowed, and offered medicine, saying:
My child was ignorant. I wish to spring forth water to make amends for my mistake.

After she finished speaking, she disappeared. Looking around the place where he was sitting, there was a gushing spring. At that time, it was said that the deity of Mount Jiuzhi had sprung forth a spring for his use.
During the Tianbao era of the Tang dynasty, Li Bai visited this mountain and called it Mount Jiuhua.
The local legend says that the mountain deity is a woman.
Many of the peaks are often shrouded in clouds and mist, and the summit is rarely exposed.
Zang originally vowed to uphold the four major Buddhist scriptures, so he went down the mountain to Naling, where a faithful layperson copied them for him, so he was able to return to the mountain.

In the first year of Zhide, Zhuge Jie led the village elders to climb the mountain from the foot, deeply thinking that there was no one there, and the clouds and sun were rarely clear. The only one living was Zang, alone in a stone chamber with his eyes closed.
In his room there was a tripod with a broken leg, in which white clay was mixed with a little rice, cooked and eaten.
The group of elders marveled and said:
The master's ascetic practices are due to our fault of living in the mountains below.
They all built a Chan monastery together, and in a few years it became a large monastery.
In the beginning of the Jianzhong era, Zhang Gongyan, the prefect of the prefecture, admired Zang's lofty style, and moved the old name to establish the temple.
His home country heard of this and led people to cross the sea to search for him. His disciples were numerous, and there was no way to support them for the year.
The master then dug into the rock and obtained soil, which was blue and white in color, not rough like flour, and used it to feed the assembly.
The assembly requested the Dharma to nourish their spirits, not to sustain their lives with food.
In the south, it was called the emaciated assembly, and none did not revere it.
Beside Longtan, there was a white clay spring, which was inexhaustible.
In the summer of the nineteenth year of the Zhenyuan era, he suddenly called the assembly to take leave, not knowing where he was going.
But he heard the mountain rocks falling, and the bell neighed as if he was sitting in meditation and passed away.
He was ninety-nine years old.

His corpse was seated in a coffin, and after three years, when it was about to be placed in a stupa, his appearance was as if alive. When they lifted it, the bones and joints moved like golden locks being shaken.
Then a small pagoda was built on the South Terrace, which was the place where the master sat in meditation.
At that time, the scholar Fei Guannei wrote an account of the events, which is still extant.
In the Daming era, the monk Yingwu also recorded his virtues.

Biography of Shen Xuan of Mount Jinhua, Jinhua Prefecture, Tang Dynasty Biography of Shen Xuan of Mount Jinhua, Jinhua Prefecture, Tang Dynasty Monk Shen Xuan, with the secular surname Liu, was from Jianyang.
From a young age, he was deep and still, not speaking unless asked.
He traveled to Wuzhu and entered Kaiyuan Temple, vowing to leave the household life there.
Soon, the prefect of his home prefecture entered the temple to visit his teacher and saw Xuan's radiant spirit.
The prefect, who was good at physiognomy, looked at him several times and said:

This child is truly a vessel for leaving the dusts. In the future, he will receive the profound Dharma and be surrounded by a thousand people. He will surely transcend the supreme fruit, not an ordinary person.
He then recited the Seven Buddhas' Juti Divine Spell, day and night without ceasing.

After receiving the precepts, he stayed in a stone cave at Baijiayan to the north of Mount Jinhua. There was a stone cave there. Xuan stayed there to rest, not building a hut, practicing open-air asceticism.
There were no beds or mats, but there was a divine person who emitted purple cloud qi and covered it high - seen from afar, it was like a solitary pillar pavilion.
The divine person sometimes came to ask about the Way, and said to Xuan with folded hands:
To the east of the Red Pine Cave, there is a forest and spring that are exceptionally outstanding. Can the master reside there?
Xuan followed the request and stayed there for several years, and many auspicious omens appeared.
In the second year of the Zhenyuan era, he met Chan Master Zhixian, who asked Xuan, If you recite mantras like this, demonic events will surely arise.
If you want to destroy demonic enemies, you must understand the origin of the body.
Since the origin of the body is true, there are no demons and no buddhas. Suddenly enlightened, both principle and phenomena are accomplished, and the power of the divine mantra is doubled.
In the eighth year of the Yuanhe era, Fan Xiangzhong, the Prefect of Yang, sent an envoy to offer Xuan milk incense, felt carpets, and utensils, all of which were given back to the present assembly.
Next, Wang Zhong, the Secretariat Drafter.
He requested to receive the bodhisattva precepts for the assembly at Dayun Temple.
For twelve years, he declined the invitation of Meng Jian, the Minister of Pingchang, from Kuaiji, and did not go.
In the eighth month, he suddenly returned to his old mountain, and people did not understand.
He suddenly said he was passing away, at the age of seventy-six.
His disciples built a stupa for him.
One says that Xuan was north of Mount Jinhua, with much cold and little yang.
A spirit asked:
What do you need, Master?
He said:
I am on the mountain's shady side, suffering from the biting cold. The spirit said:
It's a small matter.

Shi Yuan Guan, whose place of origin is unknown.

He lived in the Lu residence, leading a simple life, sometimes diligently studying the scriptures while also enjoying business. He obtained the benefits of fields and gardens, and people of the time called him a reclining gate.
His unusual deeds outside of this, he was also proficient in music. In the end of the Dali era, he became an intimate friend with Li Yuan.

Yuan's father, Cong, was a magistrate. At the end of the Tianbao era, he fell into the hands of bandits. He then donated the family property to Huilin Temple north of Luoyang City - which was Cong's private villa - as inexhaustible funds for public use.
But only one utensil was provided daily, and the monks ate together.
This went on for three years.
Li enjoyed taking elixirs and suddenly planned to travel with Guan to Qincheng and Mount Emei in Shu to seek medicine.
Guan wanted to travel to Chang'an via the Xagu Pass.
Li wanted to go through Jingzhou to enter the Gorges. They argued over these two routes for half a year without deciding.
Li said:
I have already ceased serving kings and nobles, and I do not wish to travel the roads of the two capitals.
Guan said:
Traveling has no fixed destination, please follow your son's orders.
So he went up the Gorges from Jingzhou, and when they stopped at Nanpu, he saw several women with silk sashes and brocade pendants, carrying jars to fetch water.
Guan lowered his head and wept, saying:
I did not want to pass through here, fearing I would see these women.
Li said:
Since coming up the Gorges, there have been quite a few of them, why weep alone?
Guan said:
The pregnant woman Wang is the one I entrusted myself to.
It has already been over three years, and she has not yet given birth, only because of my future.
Now that I have been seen, my life has a place to return to. What the Buddhist scriptures call 'cyclic existence.'
Please use talismans and spells to send her to give birth quickly, and stay a little longer to row my boat to bury me in the mountains and valleys.
When the family bathes the child, also look forward to the gentleman visiting.
If you glance at each other and smile, that is recognizing the gentleman.
In twelve years, on the night of the Mid-Autumn Festival, specifically outside Tianzhu Temple in Qiantang, that is the time to meet with the gentleman.
Li regretted this one act, causing Guan to come to this, grieving almost to the point of death.
He summoned the pregnant woman and told her about it, and the woman was overjoyed.
Soon, relatives gathered, and with dried fish and turbid wine, they went to the water's edge.
Li went to give them the talismanic water.
Guan had a full bath and changed into new clothes.
Seeing that she was dead, the pregnant woman gave birth.
Three days later, Li went to see the new child, and when it was held up to the light, it indeed smiled.
Li wept and told Wang Shi in detail, and Wang Shi gave Guan a lavish burial.
The next day, Li rowed back to Huilin Temple, and when he inquired about his disciples, he found out that Guan had already passed away.
Li Chang remembered the appointment in Hangzhou.

On the appointed day, he arrived at Tianzhu Mountain Temple. That night, the moon was bright. Suddenly, he heard a shepherd boy singing Bamboo Branches by the well of Ge Hong. Riding on a cow, tapping its horns, with double buns and a short robe, he slowly arrived in front of the temple. It was Guan.
Li rushed to bow and said:
Is Master Guan well?
He said:
Master Li is a true believer.
You and I have different paths, so do not come near me.
Your worldly ties are not yet exhausted, so just diligently practice and avoid falling, and you will eventually meet me.
Li had no way to explain, and looked on with tears.
Guan then sang Bamboo Branches and disappeared into the distance. The lyrics were touching and the tune was high, and no one knew what it meant.
He sighed:
He is truly a monk who has attained the Way!
Even though we are separated by a mere few feet, the paths of sages and ordinary people are different. Is it really so?

When Yuan was eight years old, he was captured by a group of bandits. He wandered in the north and south, going from one family to another, for a total of six or seven years, before returning to his relatives.
Emperor Dezong heard about this and appointed him as a clerk in the Hedong region.
Yuan then stopped drinking alcohol and eating meat, did not marry, and did not employ servants. He always stayed at Huilin Temple, lodging in a single room, and ate his meals with the monks.
First, he ordered a cave to be made in the wild to prepare for his final instructions. From time to time, he would go to sleep in that cave.
As for honor and disgrace, right and wrong, he treated them all equally.
At that time, Prime Minister Li Deyu recommended him, and he was appointed as a senior admonisher.
At that time, Yuan was already over eighty years old, and he refused to take up the post.
He died two years later - in the second year of the Changqing era.
The author says:
If one hears that Yuan died first and then entrusted his spirit to a womb, one will certainly not believe it.
Why is that?
It contradicts the teachings of the sages.
I have heard that in the Minni region, the wives of prominent families give birth to daughters, saying come here.
When they die, some have red marks on their thighs. On that day, there are families that give birth to sons with red marks on their bodies, with the two characters come here.
There are also many such cases.
What Zhuangzi called the crooked scholar cannot be spoken to about the Way is because they are bound by teachings.

There may be different theories in the Western Regions, with teachings not yet coming to the Buddha, or perhaps they were discussed in other assemblies, but there are those who believe in their own school.
If so, it is not yet possible to definitively uphold the teachings that are already practiced.

As for the view, it is indeed a profound realization, the same as the many kinds of inconceivability in the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom, with the thinking mind and discussion, a thousand miles away from being able to catch up.

The Biography of Dharma Treasury of the Five Elders Peak in Mount Lu, Jiangzhou, Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Dharma Treasury of the Five Elders Peak in Mount Lu, Jiangzhou, Tang Dynasty. The monk Dharma Treasury, with the secular surname Zhou, was from Nanfeng.
From a young age, he was sharp and outstanding. He first studied historical texts and became skilled in medical prescriptions, just like the marvelous application of Zhi Facu.
There was a monk named Meng who was seriously ill and almost incurable. Zang felt his pulse and prescribed medicine, and within a few days, he recovered.
The monk often discussed profound matters with him. Since then, he began to have the intention of leaving the dust.
When he was already an adult, he earnestly said goodbye to his parents and went to Baoyi Temple on Mount Pingtian in his prefecture to follow Master Yuan and receive teachings and precepts.
Later, he visited Chan Master Daji, whose words and teachings were like a stone thrown into water.

He went north to Mount Lu in a carefree manner and climbed the Five Elders Peak. He loved its spiritual wonders and stayed alone in the Cold Forest, picking acorns and cupping creek water to barely sustain himself for several years.
Two immortals rode on clouds and came, talking with him all day. Sometimes they stayed overnight, sometimes they didn't come for a month, sometimes they came back to back.
Other people who saw them described it differently.
When the learned monks gathered, there was no trace of him.
One day he said goodbye to Zang, saying:
I will return to the mountains, and the master should stay well.
Thus, his way became fragrant, and the donors built an abbey together.
He passed away in the Baili year, at the age of eighty-two.

Tang Dynasty, Biography of Jingkong of Xiangshan Temple in Luoyang, Tang Dynasty, Biography of Jingkong of Xiangshan Temple in Luoyang, Shi Jingkong, whose secular surname was Qi, was a person from Wu County.
From a young age, he suffered from poverty. Although he diligently studied, he had little to memorize.
In his prime, he wrote poetry, not much of it was elegant.
He often traveled between Wu and Chu for four or five years.
He sought favors from lords and marquises, but received little benefit.
Whenever he had some money, he would fall ill, and only get better when he spent it all.
In the beginning of the Yuanhe era, he traveled to Qiantang, which was then in a state of desolation and poverty. He then planned to seek a meal at Tianzhu Temple.
When he reached the west of Gushan Temple, he was so hungry that he could not go on, so he wept by the stream and wailed several times.
Suddenly, a Sanskrit monk sat by the stream and said with a smile,
Dharma Master Xiucai, is the taste of travel enough?
Kong said,
The taste of travel is already enough.
Why does the Dharma Master call me so strangely?
This was because Kong's name was Junfang before he became a monk.
The Sanskrit monk said,
Do you not remember lecturing on the Lotus Sutra at Tongde Temple?
Kong said:
I have already been alive for forty-five years. I have wandered in the regions of Wu and Chu, and have never set foot in Jingkou.
How could there be any talk of Luoyang?
The monk said:
You must be so hungry that you cannot remember past events.
He then took out a jujube from his bag, as big as a fist, and said:
This is produced in our country. Those who eat it, the most intelligent ones know past and future events, while the less intelligent ones only know about their past lives.
Kong, who was extremely hungry, ate the jujube and drank some spring water.
He suddenly yawned, leaned on a rock and fell asleep. In a moment he woke up and remembered lecturing on the sutra at Tongde Temple as if it were yesterday.
He then wept even more and asked the monk:
Where is Master Zhen now?
The monk said:
Your concentration is not yet sufficient. You are now a monk from Shu.
Now, I will cut off clinging.
Where is the Venerable Shen now?
He said:
My previous vow has not been fulfilled.
Where is Master Wu?
He said:
Didn't you remember the great vow you playfully made in front of the stone image on Fragrant Mountain?
If you do not attain supreme enlightenment, you vow to become a powerful and noble minister.
I heard yesterday that you have already become a great general.
At that time, among the five of us who were wandering monks, only I have attained liberation, while you alone are a person suffering from hunger and cold.
Kong wept and said:
For over forty years, I have only eaten one meal a day, and for over thirty years, I have only worn one robe. I have completely cut off worldly affairs.
Why is it that my blessings are incomplete?
I am sitting in hunger and cold.
The monk said:
Because you widely expounded heterodox teachings from the lion's seat, causing those who study emptiness to give rise to doubt.
The pearl of precepts has been flawed, and the smell of sheep still lingers slightly. A dull voice and clear echo cannot be achieved in the end.
A hunchback's shadow is crooked. Retribution and response should be so.
Kong said:
What can be done about it?
The monk said:
As for today's matter, I have no plan.
As for the matter of future lives, I warn you, my son.
He then searched his alms bowl bag and took out a mirror, the back and front of which were both clear and penetrating, and said to Kong:
If you want to know the distinction between noble and humble, the length of life, the rise and fall of the Buddha's teachings, and the prosperity and decline of my way, you should look into it.
Kong looked at it for a long time and thanked him, saying:
I have carefully understood the matter of retribution and the principle of glory and decline.
The monk put the mirror back into the bag and left, walking for more than ten steps, then suddenly disappearing.
Kong that night took refuge in Lingyin Temple to become a monk and received full ordination.
Later, he traveled to famous mountains, becoming even more lofty and austere.
In the first year of the Dali era, he went to Luoyang and met Liu Cheng of Hedong at Tianzhu Temple in Longmen. He personally told Liu Cheng his story.
Liu Cheng heard the unusual things that happened in the sky, and was greatly amazed.
Kong said:
I have lived in the world for seventy-seven years, and have been a monk for thirty-two years. I still have nine years to beg for food with my alms bowl.
When I leave this world, will the Buddha Dharma decline?
Liu Cheng asked about this, but he remained silent and did not answer.
He then asked for Liu Cheng's brush and ink, wrote several lines on the northern wall of the Sutra Repository, and left.
He said:
One monk who is prosperous is like a monk in the Ganges River. Rabbits are trapped, dogs are caught, cows and tigers interact with horns and tusks, but the precious sandalwood will never wither.
The author says:
The one who knew his past life by eating the jujube of the Indian monk is the same as the one who understood the languages of various countries by eating the herbs of the Himalayas.
Those who can know good and bad fortune by examining mirrors are the same as those who can see through divination and physiognomy.
Is it a coincidence to eat jujubes and look in a mirror?
It is not the encounter of an ordinary person.
The prophecy that Kong replied to Liu Cheng's question was verified in the persecution of Buddhism during the Wuchang era.

At that time, Emperor Wuzong ordered monks and nuns to return to lay life, totaling more than 207,000 people. Temples and hermitages were demolished, totaling over 47,000. Therefore, it is said, One flourishing monk, ten thousand decaying monks, the rabbit is caught in the trap, the dog still bites. It describes the extreme harm.
In the second year of Yichou, the Dharma was destroyed, and in the third year of Bingyin, the emperor died.
The Buddha Dharma is likened to a sandalwood tree, which never ceases to bloom and emit fragrance. Therefore, it is said.
If it were not for extraordinary people, how could they have hidden the past and examined the future to such an extent?
Biography of Dao-xing of Mount Luofu in Guangzhou, Tang Dynasty Biography of Dao-xing of Mount Luofu in Guangzhou, Tang Dynasty Shi Dao-xing, whose surname was Mei, was a person from Kuaiji.

Many of the beings he encountered had similar experiences.
In the ninth year of the Baoli era, he passed away due to illness, at the age of ninety-five.

Biography of Qing Guan of Guoqing Temple on Mount Tiantai in the Tang Dynasty, Biography of Qing Guan of Guoqing Temple on Mount Tiantai in the Tang Dynasty, Shi Qing Guan, whose pseudonym was Ming Zhong, was a person from Linhai, with the surname Qu.
When he was first born, his hands and feet were webbed, which is the mark of a Buddha in the Buddhist scriptures.
When he became a child, his spirit was outstanding, and he had the aspiration to leave the dust.
He then went to Guoqing Temple and served as an attendant to Vinaya Master Yuan Zhang.
If it were not for his parents, he would have been like a garuá¸a bird pecking through thousands of layers of barriers.

At the age of eighteen, he took the tonsure and became a monk. Because of his deep planting of wholesome roots, his understanding was natural. He thoroughly understood the teachings and texts of Mount Tiantai and the three contemplations, and also attained profound concentration. His spiritual abilities and responses were all beyond the comprehension of others.
In his youth, he read a hundred schools of thought and thoroughly understood the Three Teachings.
He was also good at writing and excelled in poetry and prose.
Whenever the feudal lords came in light carriages, they all came to pay homage, and when they saw him, they treated him with the utmost respect as if he were a stern ruler.
When they saw him, they were in awe and submission, and he would only receive the noble ones while sitting on a chair with a cane.
If they offered him wealth and treasures, he would all return them to the permanent residence, not keeping anything for himself.
Some said:
The noble ones' offerings are all used for separate offerings. Why don't you use them yourself?
He replied:
I regret that I am unable to give away my head and eyes, let alone worldly wealth.

In the beginning of the Dazhong era, the temples and monasteries of the world were revived. Guan entered the capital to request a large bell to be returned to the temple for striking, and also to have the imperial edict inscription, which was written by Liu Gongquan, a scholar of the Jixian Academy.
Liu also wrote a preface and a poem to see him off on his return to the east.
He also requested the canon scriptures to be returned to the temple.
In the 10th year of the Dazhong era, the Jiangnan region suffered a severe famine, with corpses lying side by side. Guan then combined the grain and food to distribute it.
Moreover, the master spent his years in seclusion, entering the room for Chan meditation, and said to his disciples:
If you do not die, when the grain ripens, you should use the bell to lead me out.
Sure enough, as he said, the following year he arose from his concentration.
One day, he was invited to a vegetarian feast by the people south of the creek, more than twenty li away from the temple.
That night, the creek overflowed, and no one could cross it, so they said Guan would not come.
But in an instant, he arrived, and his clothes were not even wet. His abilities were known to all, and people marveled at him.
People from far and near paid homage to him, filling the place every day. He became tired of the noise and commotion, so he fled to the secluded monastery on Mount Cuiping and lived alone.
The assembly on Mount Tiantai continued to request him to be the monastic head, but he feigned madness and hid himself.
The prefect Du Xiong then reported to Emperor Xizong, who bestowed purple robes on him. When Guan heard of this, he seemed worried and unhappy.
Later, he passed away without illness.
Biography of Xiyun of Mount Huangbo in Hongzhou, Tang Dynasty Biography of Xiyun of Mount Huangbo in Hongzhou, Tang Dynasty Shi Xiyun was a man from Fujian.
When he reached school age, his village school praised his intelligence.
He then cut off his love and left home to become a monk at Huangbo Temple on Mount Gao'an.
By the time he grew up, his body was only a foot shorter than a king's merchant, and a protuberance on his forehead was called a flesh pearl.
However, he was unconventional and unrestrained, and no one dared to underestimate him.
He then traveled to Tiantai, where he happened to meet a monk who traveled with him, speaking and laughing as usual.
Xiyun secretly glanced at him, and the monk's eyes sometimes flickered, shining brightly at people.
They walked side by side, and on the way they encountered a huge ford, overflowing with water, where they put down their rain hats and leaned on their staffs to rest.
The monk urged Xiyun to cross over, and then forcefully inspired him, saying:
If you want to cross, cross by yourself.
After saying this, the monk lifted his robe and stepped on the waves as if walking on level ground, not getting wet at all, and reached the other shore.
He turned around and beckoned with his hand, saying:
Come across.
The man with the halberd scolded:
Tsk! If I had known earlier, I would have definitely cut off your leg.
The monk sighed and said:
You are a true vessel for the Mahayana Dharma, which I am not.
Even if you could injure me, it would only bring shame upon yourself.
After a while, he disappeared.
Yun was confused and lost.
Later, when he was wandering in the capital, he went to beg for alms at a family's gate. Behind a screen of trees, he heard an old woman say:
How insatiable!
Yun said:
The host not deceiving the guest, how can there be insatiability?
The old woman called him in and gave him food.
The old woman said:
With this body of five hindrances, I have had the honor of paying homage to National Preceptor Huizhong in the past.
You should go and visit Chan Master Baizhang on Mount Baizhang. He is truly a vessel of the Great Vehicle, majestic and imposing.
Yunmen received the two admonitions and the prediction was the same. He then returned to Hongzhou to see Chan Master Hongdao, who opened up his mind and direction. His reputation became even higher.
He accepted the request to reside at Huangbo Monastery. The prime minister Pei Xiu, who admired him, personally visited him and wrote a poem as a gift:
I have heard that the seal of the mind of the enlightened ones is transmitted, with a round pearl and a seven-foot body.
Hanging the begging bowl for ten years, dwelling by the Shu River, floating the alms bowl today, crossing the Zhang River.
A thousand dragons and elephants follow his lofty steps, fragrant flowers from myriad miles form a superior cause.
I wish to serve the master as a disciple, but I do not know to whom he will entrust the Dharma.
Then Prime Minister Pei received the Dharma and left through the gate.

He passed away in the middle of the Dazhong era at the monastery where he resided. He was posthumously titled Chan Master Duanci, and his stupa was named Guangye. His recorded sayings were circulated in the world.
